62 // Forward declarations
63 struct ImDrawChannel; // Temporary storage for outputting drawing commands out of order, used by ImDrawList::ChannelsSplit()
64 struct ImDrawCmd; // A single draw command within a parent ImDrawList (generally maps to 1 GPU draw call)
65 struct ImDrawData; // All draw command lists required to render the frame
66 struct ImDrawList; // A single draw command list (generally one per window, conceptually you may see this as a dynamic "mesh" builder)
67 struct ImDrawListSharedData; // Data shared among multiple draw lists (typically owned by parent ImGui context, but you may create one yourself)
68 struct ImDrawVert; // A single vertex (20 bytes by default, override layout with IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT)
69 struct ImFont; // Runtime data for a single font within a parent ImFontAtlas
70 struct ImFontAtlas; // Runtime data for multiple fonts, bake multiple fonts into a single texture, TTF/OTF font loader
71 struct ImFontConfig; // Configuration data when adding a font or merging fonts
72 struct ImColor; // Helper functions to create a color that can be converted to either u32 or float4 (*obsolete* please avoid using)
73 #ifndef ImTextureID
74 typedef void* ImTextureID; // User data to identify a texture (this is whatever to you want it to be! read the FAQ about ImTextureID in imgui.cpp)
75 #endif
76 struct ImGuiContext; // ImGui context (opaque)
77 struct ImGuiIO; // Main configuration and I/O between your application and ImGui
78 struct ImGuiInputTextCallbackData; // Shared state of InputText() when using custom ImGuiInputTextCallback (rare/advanced use)
79 struct ImGuiListClipper; // Helper to manually clip large list of items
80 struct ImGuiOnceUponAFrame; // Helper for running a block of code not more than once a frame, used by IMGUI_ONCE_UPON_A_FRAME macro
81 struct ImGuiPayload; // User data payload for drag and drop operations
82 struct ImGuiSizeCallbackData; // Callback data when using SetNextWindowSizeConstraints() (rare/advanced use)
83 struct ImGuiStorage; // Helper for key->value storage
84 struct ImGuiStyle; // Runtime data for styling/colors
85 struct ImGuiTextFilter; // Helper to parse and apply text filters (e.g. "aaaaa[,bbbb][,ccccc]")
86 struct ImGuiTextBuffer; // Helper to hold and append into a text buffer (~string builder)

118 // Scalar data types
119 typedef signed int ImS32; // 32-bit signed integer == int
120 typedef unsigned int ImU32; // 32-bit unsigned integer (often used to store packed colors)
121 #if defined(_MSC_VER) && !defined(__clang__)
122 typedef signed __int64 ImS64; // 64-bit signed integer (pre and post C++11 with Visual Studio)
123 typedef unsigned __int64 ImU64; // 64-bit unsigned integer (pre and post C++11 with Visual Studio)
124 #elif (defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__)) && (__cplusplus < 201100)
125 #include <stdint.h>
126 typedef int64_t ImS64; // 64-bit signed integer (pre C++11)
127 typedef uint64_t ImU64; // 64-bit unsigned integer (pre C++11)
128 #else
129 typedef signed long long ImS64; // 64-bit signed integer (post C++11)
130 typedef unsigned long long ImU64; // 64-bit unsigned integer (post C++11)
131 #endif

133 // 2D vector (often used to store positions, sizes, etc.)
134 struct ImVec2
135 {
136  float x, y;
137  ImVec2() { x = y = 0.0f; }
138  ImVec2(float _x, float _y) { x = _x; y = _y; }
139  float operator[] (size_t i) const { IM_ASSERT(i <= 1); return (&x)[i]; } // We very rarely use this [] operator, the assert overhead is fine.
140 #ifdef IM_VEC2_CLASS_EXTRA
141  IM_VEC2_CLASS_EXTRA // Define additional constructors and implicit cast operators in imconfig.h to convert back and forth between your math types and ImVec2.
142 #endif
143 };
144 
145 // 4D vector (often used to store floating-point colors)
146 struct ImVec4
147 {
148  float x, y, z, w;
149  ImVec4() { x = y = z = w = 0.0f; }
150  ImVec4(float _x, float _y, float _z, float _w) { x = _x; y = _y; z = _z; w = _w; }
151 #ifdef IM_VEC4_CLASS_EXTRA
152  IM_VEC4_CLASS_EXTRA // Define additional constructors and implicit cast operators in imconfig.h to convert back and forth between your math types and ImVec4.
153 #endif
154 };

171  IMGUI_API ImGuiStyle& GetStyle(); // access the Style structure (colors, sizes). Always use PushStyleCol(), PushStyleVar() to modify style mid-frame.
172  IMGUI_API void NewFrame(); // start a new ImGui frame, you can submit any command from this point until Render()/EndFrame().
173  IMGUI_API void EndFrame(); // ends the ImGui frame. automatically called by Render(), you likely don't need to call that yourself directly. If you don't need to render data (skipping rendering) you may call EndFrame() but you'll have wasted CPU already! If you don't need to render, better to not create any imgui windows and not call NewFrame() at all!
174  IMGUI_API void Render(); // ends the ImGui frame, finalize the draw data. (Obsolete: optionally call io.RenderDrawListsFn if set. Nowadays, prefer calling your render function yourself.)
175  IMGUI_API ImDrawData* GetDrawData(); // valid after Render() and until the next call to NewFrame(). this is what you have to render. (Obsolete: this used to be passed to your io.RenderDrawListsFn() function.)

191  // Windows
192  // - Begin() = push window to the stack and start appending to it. End() = pop window from the stack.
193  // - You may append multiple times to the same window during the same frame.
194  // - Passing 'bool* p_open != NULL' shows a window-closing widget in the upper-right corner of the window, which clicking will set the boolean to false when clicked.
195  // - Begin() return false to indicate the window is collapsed or fully clipped, so you may early out and omit submitting anything to the window.
196  // Always call a matching End() for each Begin() call, regardless of its return value [this is due to legacy reason and is inconsistent with most other functions such as BeginMenu/EndMenu, BeginPopup/EndPopup, etc. where the EndXXX call should only be called if the corresponding BeginXXX function returned true.]
197  IMGUI_API bool Begin(const char* name, bool* p_open = NULL, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0);
198  IMGUI_API void End();
199 
200  // Child Windows
201  // - Use child windows to begin into a self-contained independent scrolling/clipping regions within a host window. Child windows can embed their own child.
202  // - For each independent axis of 'size': ==0.0f: use remaining host window size / >0.0f: fixed size / <0.0f: use remaining window size minus abs(size) / Each axis can use a different mode, e.g. ImVec2(0,400).
203  // - BeginChild() returns false to indicate the window is collapsed or fully clipped, so you may early out and omit submitting anything to the window.
204  // Always call a matching EndChild() for each BeginChild() call, regardless of its return value [this is due to legacy reason and is inconsistent with most other functions such as BeginMenu/EndMenu, BeginPopup/EndPopup, etc. where the EndXXX call should only be called if the corresponding BeginXXX function returned true.]
205  IMGUI_API bool BeginChild(const char* str_id, const ImVec2& size = ImVec2(0,0), bool border = false, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0);
206  IMGUI_API bool BeginChild(ImGuiID id, const ImVec2& size = ImVec2(0,0), bool border = false, ImGuiWindowFlags flags = 0);
207  IMGUI_API void EndChild();

306  // ID stack/scopes
307  // Read the FAQ for more details about how ID are handled in dear imgui. If you are creating widgets in a loop you most
308  // likely want to push a unique identifier (e.g. object pointer, loop index) to uniquely differentiate them.
309  // You can also use the "##foobar" syntax within widget label to distinguish them from each others.
310  // In this header file we use the "label"/"name" terminology to denote a string that will be displayed and used as an ID,
311  // whereas "str_id" denote a string that is only used as an ID and not aimed to be displayed.
312  IMGUI_API void PushID(const char* str_id); // push identifier into the ID stack. IDs are hash of the entire stack!

619  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoScrollbar = 1 << 3, // Disable scrollbars (window can still scroll with mouse or programatically)
620  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoScrollWithMouse = 1 << 4, // Disable user vertically scrolling with mouse wheel. On child window, mouse wheel will be forwarded to the parent unless NoScrollbar is also set.
621  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoCollapse = 1 << 5, // Disable user collapsing window by double-clicking on it
622  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysAutoResize = 1 << 6, // Resize every window to its content every frame
623  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoBackground = 1 << 7, // Disable drawing background color (WindowBg, etc.) and outside border. Similar as using SetNextWindowBgAlpha(0.0f).
624  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoSavedSettings = 1 << 8, // Never load/save settings in .ini file
625  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoMouseInputs = 1 << 9, // Disable catching mouse, hovering test with pass through.
626  ImGuiWindowFlags_MenuBar = 1 << 10, // Has a menu-bar
627  ImGuiWindowFlags_HorizontalScrollbar = 1 << 11, // Allow horizontal scrollbar to appear (off by default). You may use SetNextWindowContentSize(ImVec2(width,0.0f)); prior to calling Begin() to specify width. Read code in imgui_demo in the "Horizontal Scrolling" section.
628  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoFocusOnAppearing = 1 << 12, // Disable taking focus when transitioning from hidden to visible state
629  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoBringToFrontOnFocus = 1 << 13, // Disable bringing window to front when taking focus (e.g. clicking on it or programatically giving it focus)
630  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysVerticalScrollbar= 1 << 14, // Always show vertical scrollbar (even if ContentSize.y < Size.y)
631  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysHorizontalScrollbar=1<< 15, // Always show horizontal scrollbar (even if ContentSize.x < Size.x)
632  ImGuiWindowFlags_AlwaysUseWindowPadding = 1 << 16, // Ensure child windows without border uses style.WindowPadding (ignored by default for non-bordered child windows, because more convenient)
633  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs = 1 << 18, // No gamepad/keyboard navigation within the window
634  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavFocus = 1 << 19, // No focusing toward this window with gamepad/keyboard navigation (e.g. skipped by CTRL+TAB)
635  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNav = ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavFocus,
636  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoDecoration = ImGuiWindowFlags_NoTitleBar | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoResize | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoScrollbar | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoCollapse,
637  ImGuiWindowFlags_NoInputs = ImGuiWindowFlags_NoMouseInputs | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavInputs | ImGuiWindowFlags_NoNavFocus,
638 
639  // [Internal]
640  ImGuiWindowFlags_NavFlattened = 1 << 23, // [BETA] Allow gamepad/keyboard navigation to cross over parent border to this child (only use on child that have no scrolling!)
641  ImGuiWindowFlags_ChildWindow = 1 << 24, // Don't use! For internal use by BeginChild()
642  ImGuiWindowFlags_Tooltip = 1 << 25, // Don't use! For internal use by BeginTooltip()
643  ImGuiWindowFlags_Popup = 1 << 26, // Don't use! For internal use by BeginPopup()

Notify when the string wants to be resized (for string types which hold a cache of their Size). You will be provided a new BufSize in the callback and NEED to honor it. (see misc/cpp/imgui_stdlib.h for an example of using this)

739 // Flags for ImGui::IsItemHovered(), ImGui::IsWindowHovered()

751  ImGuiHoveredFlags_AllowWhenOverlapped = 1 << 6, // Return true even if the position is overlapped by another window
752  ImGuiHoveredFlags_AllowWhenDisabled = 1 << 7, // Return true even if the item is disabled

757 // Flags for ImGui::BeginDragDropSource(), ImGui::AcceptDragDropPayload()
758 enum ImGuiDragDropFlags_
759 {
760  ImGuiDragDropFlags_None = 0,
761  // BeginDragDropSource() flags
762  ImGuiDragDropFlags_SourceNoPreviewTooltip = 1 << 0, // By default, a successful call to BeginDragDropSource opens a tooltip so you can display a preview or description of the source contents. This flag disable this behavior.
763  ImGuiDragDropFlags_SourceNoDisableHover = 1 << 1, // By default, when dragging we clear data so that IsItemHovered() will return false, to avoid subsequent user code submitting tooltips. This flag disable this behavior so you can still call IsItemHovered() on the source item.
764  ImGuiDragDropFlags_SourceNoHoldToOpenOthers = 1 << 2, // Disable the behavior that allows to open tree nodes and collapsing header by holding over them while dragging a source item.
765  ImGuiDragDropFlags_SourceAllowNullID = 1 << 3, // Allow items such as Text(), Image() that have no unique identifier to be used as drag source, by manufacturing a temporary identifier based on their window-relative position. This is extremely unusual within the dear imgui ecosystem and so we made it explicit.
766  ImGuiDragDropFlags_SourceExtern = 1 << 4, // External source (from outside of imgui), won't attempt to read current item/window info. Will always return true. Only one Extern source can be active simultaneously.
767  ImGuiDragDropFlags_SourceAutoExpirePayload = 1 << 5, // Automatically expire the payload if the source cease to be submitted (otherwise payloads are persisting while being dragged)
768  // AcceptDragDropPayload() flags
769  ImGuiDragDropFlags_AcceptBeforeDelivery = 1 << 10, // AcceptDragDropPayload() will returns true even before the mouse button is released. You can then call IsDelivery() to test if the payload needs to be delivered.
770  ImGuiDragDropFlags_AcceptNoDrawDefaultRect = 1 << 11, // Do not draw the default highlight rectangle when hovering over target.
771  ImGuiDragDropFlags_AcceptNoPreviewTooltip = 1 << 12, // Request hiding the BeginDragDropSource tooltip from the BeginDragDropTarget site.
772  ImGuiDragDropFlags_AcceptPeekOnly = ImGuiDragDropFlags_AcceptBeforeDelivery | ImGuiDragDropFlags_AcceptNoDrawDefaultRect // For peeking ahead and inspecting the payload before delivery.
773 };

829 // Gamepad/Keyboard directional navigation

831 // Gamepad: Set io.ConfigFlags |= ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableGamepad to enable. Back-end: set ImGuiBackendFlags_HasGamepad and fill the io.NavInputs[] fields before calling NewFrame(). Note that io.NavInputs[] is cleared by EndFrame().

842  ImGuiNavInput_DpadUp, //

864 // Configuration flags stored in io.ConfigFlags. Set by user/application.
865 enum ImGuiConfigFlags_
866 {
867  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableKeyboard = 1 << 0, // Master keyboard navigation enable flag. NewFrame() will automatically fill io.NavInputs[] based on io.KeysDown[].
868  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableGamepad = 1 << 1, // Master gamepad navigation enable flag. This is mostly to instruct your imgui back-end to fill io.NavInputs[]. Back-end also needs to set ImGuiBackendFlags_HasGamepad.
869  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavEnableSetMousePos = 1 << 2, // Instruct navigation to move the mouse cursor. May be useful on TV/console systems where moving a virtual mouse is awkward. Will update io.MousePos and set io.WantSetMousePos=true. If enabled you MUST honor io.WantSetMousePos requests in your binding, otherwise ImGui will react as if the mouse is jumping around back and forth.
870  ImGuiConfigFlags_NavNoCaptureKeyboard = 1 << 3, // Instruct navigation to not set the io.WantCaptureKeyboard flag when io.NavActive is set.
871  ImGuiConfigFlags_NoMouse = 1 << 4, // Instruct imgui to clear mouse position/buttons in NewFrame(). This allows ignoring the mouse information set by the back-end.
872  ImGuiConfigFlags_NoMouseCursorChange = 1 << 5, // Instruct back-end to not alter mouse cursor shape and visibility. Use if the back-end cursor changes are interfering with yours and you don't want to use SetMouseCursor() to change mouse cursor. You may want to honor requests from imgui by reading GetMouseCursor() yourself instead.
873 
874  // User storage (to allow your back-end/engine to communicate to code that may be shared between multiple projects. Those flags are not used by core ImGui)
875  ImGuiConfigFlags_IsSRGB = 1 << 20, // Application is SRGB-aware.
876  ImGuiConfigFlags_IsTouchScreen = 1 << 21 // Application is using a touch screen instead of a mouse.
877 };

1049 // You may modify the ImGui::GetStyle() main instance during initialization and before NewFrame().
1050 // During the frame, use ImGui::PushStyleVar(ImGuiStyleVar_XXXX)/PopStyleVar() to alter the main style values, and ImGui::PushStyleColor(ImGuiCol_XXX)/PopStyleColor() for colors.
1051 struct ImGuiStyle
1052 {
1053  float Alpha; // Global alpha applies to everything in ImGui.
1054  ImVec2 WindowPadding; // Padding within a window.
1055  float WindowRounding; // Radius of window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows.
1056  float WindowBorderSize; // Thickness of border around windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1057  ImVec2 WindowMinSize; // Minimum window size. This is a global setting. If you want to constraint individual windows, use SetNextWindowSizeConstraints().
1058  ImVec2 WindowTitleAlign; // Alignment for title bar text. Defaults to (0.0f,0.5f) for left-aligned,vertically centered.
1059  float ChildRounding; // Radius of child window corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular windows.
1060  float ChildBorderSize; // Thickness of border around child windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1061  float PopupRounding; // Radius of popup window corners rounding. (Note that tooltip windows use WindowRounding)
1062  float PopupBorderSize; // Thickness of border around popup/tooltip windows. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1063  ImVec2 FramePadding; // Padding within a framed rectangle (used by most widgets).
1064  float FrameRounding; // Radius of frame corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular frame (used by most widgets).
1065  float FrameBorderSize; // Thickness of border around frames. Generally set to 0.0f or 1.0f. (Other values are not well tested and more CPU/GPU costly).
1066  ImVec2 ItemSpacing; // Horizontal and vertical spacing between widgets/lines.
1067  ImVec2 ItemInnerSpacing; // Horizontal and vertical spacing between within elements of a composed widget (e.g. a slider and its label).
1068  ImVec2 TouchExtraPadding; // Expand reactive bounding box for touch-based system where touch position is not accurate enough. Unfortunately we don't sort widgets so priority on overlap will always be given to the first widget. So don't grow this too much!
1069  float IndentSpacing; // Horizontal indentation when e.g. entering a tree node. Generally == (FontSize + FramePadding.x*2).
1070  float ColumnsMinSpacing; // Minimum horizontal spacing between two columns.
1071  float ScrollbarSize; // Width of the vertical scrollbar, Height of the horizontal scrollbar.
1072  float ScrollbarRounding; // Radius of grab corners for scrollbar.
1073  float GrabMinSize; // Minimum width/height of a grab box for slider/scrollbar.
1074  float GrabRounding; // Radius of grabs corners rounding. Set to 0.0f to have rectangular slider grabs.
1075  ImVec2 ButtonTextAlign; // Alignment of button text when button is larger than text. Defaults to (0.5f,0.5f) for horizontally+vertically centered.
1076  ImVec2 DisplayWindowPadding; // Window position are clamped to be visible within the display area by at least this amount. Only applies to regular windows.
1077  ImVec2 DisplaySafeAreaPadding; // If you cannot see the edges of your screen (e.g. on a TV) increase the safe area padding. Apply to popups/tooltips as well regular windows. NB: Prefer configuring your TV sets correctly!
1078  float MouseCursorScale; // Scale software rendered mouse cursor (when io.MouseDrawCursor is enabled). May be removed later.
1079  bool AntiAliasedLines; // Enable anti-aliasing on lines/borders. Disable if you are really tight on CPU/GPU.
1080  bool AntiAliasedFill; // Enable anti-aliasing on filled shapes (rounded rectangles, circles, etc.)
1081  float CurveTessellationTol; // Tessellation tolerance when using PathBezierCurveTo() without a specific number of segments. Decrease for highly tessellated curves (higher quality, more polygons), increase to reduce quality.
1082  ImVec4 Colors[ImGuiCol_COUNT];
1083 
1084  IMGUI_API ImGuiStyle();
1085  IMGUI_API void ScaleAllSizes(float scale_factor);
1086 };

1255 // Helper: Lightweight std::vector<> like class to avoid dragging dependencies (also: Windows implementation of STL with debug enabled is absurdly slow, so let's bypass it so our code runs fast in debug).
1256 // *Important* Our implementation does NOT call C++ constructors/destructors. This is intentional, we do not require it but you have to be mindful of that. Do _not_ use this class as a std::vector replacement in your code!
1257 template<typename T>
1258 class ImVector
1259 {
1260 public:
1261  int Size;
1262  int Capacity;
1263  T* Data;
1264 
1265  typedef T value_type;
1266  typedef value_type* iterator;
1267  typedef const value_type* const_iterator;
1268 
1269  inline ImVector() { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; }
1270  inline ~ImVector() { if (Data) ImGui::MemFree(Data); }
1271  inline ImVector(const ImVector<T>& src) { Size = Capacity = 0; Data = NULL; operator=(src); }
1272  inline ImVector<T>& operator=(const ImVector<T>& src) { clear(); resize(src.Size); memcpy(Data, src.Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(value_type)); return *this; }
1273 
1274  inline bool empty() const { return Size == 0; }
1275  inline int size() const { return Size; }
1276  inline int capacity() const { return Capacity; }
1277  inline value_type& operator[](int i) { IM_ASSERT(i < Size); return Data[i]; }
1278  inline const value_type& operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(i < Size); return Data[i]; }
1279 
1280  inline void clear() { if (Data) { Size = Capacity = 0; ImGui::MemFree(Data); Data = NULL; } }
1281  inline iterator begin() { return Data; }
1282  inline const_iterator begin() const { return Data; }
1283  inline iterator end() { return Data + Size; }
1284  inline const_iterator end() const { return Data + Size; }
1285  inline value_type& front() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; }
1286  inline const value_type& front() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[0]; }
1287  inline value_type& back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; }
1288  inline const value_type& back() const { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); return Data[Size - 1]; }
1289  inline void swap(ImVector<value_type>& rhs) { int rhs_size = rhs.Size; rhs.Size = Size; Size = rhs_size; int rhs_cap = rhs.Capacity; rhs.Capacity = Capacity; Capacity = rhs_cap; value_type* rhs_data = rhs.Data; rhs.Data = Data; Data = rhs_data; }
1290 
1291  inline int _grow_capacity(int sz) const { int new_capacity = Capacity ? (Capacity + Capacity/2) : 8; return new_capacity > sz ? new_capacity : sz; }
1292  inline void resize(int new_size) { if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); Size = new_size; }
1293  inline void resize(int new_size,const value_type& v){ if (new_size > Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(new_size)); if (new_size > Size) for (int n = Size; n < new_size; n++) memcpy(&Data[n], &v, sizeof(v)); Size = new_size; }
1294  inline void reserve(int new_capacity)
1295  {
1296  if (new_capacity <= Capacity)
1297  return;
1298  value_type* new_data = (value_type*)ImGui::MemAlloc((size_t)new_capacity * sizeof(value_type));
1299  if (Data)
1300  {
1301  memcpy(new_data, Data, (size_t)Size * sizeof(value_type));
1302  ImGui::MemFree(Data);
1303  }
1304  Data = new_data;
1305  Capacity = new_capacity;
1306  }
1307 
1308  // NB: It is forbidden to call push_back/push_front/insert with a reference pointing inside the ImVector data itself! e.g. v.push_back(v[10]) is forbidden.
1309  inline void push_back(const value_type& v) { if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); memcpy(&Data[Size], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; }
1310  inline void pop_back() { IM_ASSERT(Size > 0); Size--; }
1311  inline void push_front(const value_type& v) { if (Size == 0) push_back(v); else insert(Data, v); }
1312  inline iterator erase(const_iterator it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + 1, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - 1) * sizeof(value_type)); Size--; return Data + off; }
1313  inline iterator erase(const_iterator it, const_iterator it_last){ IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data+Size && it_last > it && it_last <= Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t count = it_last - it; const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; memmove(Data + off, Data + off + count, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off - count) * sizeof(value_type)); Size -= (int)count; return Data + off; }
1314  inline iterator erase_unsorted(const_iterator it) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it < Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (it < Data+Size-1) memcpy(Data + off, Data + Size - 1, sizeof(value_type)); Size--; return Data + off; }
1315  inline iterator insert(const_iterator it, const value_type& v) { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it <= Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; if (Size == Capacity) reserve(_grow_capacity(Size + 1)); if (off < (int)Size) memmove(Data + off + 1, Data + off, ((size_t)Size - (size_t)off) * sizeof(value_type)); memcpy(&Data[off], &v, sizeof(v)); Size++; return Data + off; }
1316  inline bool contains(const value_type& v) const { const T* data = Data; const T* data_end = Data + Size; while (data < data_end) if (*data++ == v) return true; return false; }
1317  inline int index_from_pointer(const_iterator it) const { IM_ASSERT(it >= Data && it <= Data+Size); const ptrdiff_t off = it - Data; return (int)off; }
1318 };
1319 
1320 // Helper: IM_NEW(), IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(), IM_DELETE() macros to call MemAlloc + Placement New, Placement Delete + MemFree
1321 // We call C++ constructor on own allocated memory via the placement "new(ptr) Type()" syntax.
1322 // Defining a custom placement new() with a dummy parameter allows us to bypass including <new> which on some platforms complains when user has disabled exceptions.
1323 struct ImNewDummy {};
1324 inline void* operator new(size_t, ImNewDummy, void* ptr) { return ptr; }
1325 inline void operator delete(void*, ImNewDummy, void*) {} // This is only required so we can use the symetrical new()
1326 #define IM_PLACEMENT_NEW(_PTR) new(ImNewDummy(), _PTR)
1327 #define IM_NEW(_TYPE) new(ImNewDummy(), ImGui::MemAlloc(sizeof(_TYPE))) _TYPE
1328 template<typename T> void IM_DELETE(T* p) { if (p) { p->~T(); ImGui::MemFree(p); } }
1329 
1330 // Helper: Execute a block of code at maximum once a frame. Convenient if you want to quickly create an UI within deep-nested code that runs multiple times every frame.
1331 // Usage: static ImGuiOnceUponAFrame oaf; if (oaf) ImGui::Text("This will be called only once per frame");
1332 struct ImGuiOnceUponAFrame
1333 {
1334  ImGuiOnceUponAFrame() { RefFrame = -1; }
1335  mutable int RefFrame;
1336  operator bool() const { int current_frame = ImGui::GetFrameCount(); if (RefFrame == current_frame) return false; RefFrame = current_frame; return true; }
1337 };

1340 #ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS // Will obsolete
1341 #define IMGUI_ONCE_UPON_A_FRAME static ImGuiOnceUponAFrame imgui_oaf; if (imgui_oaf)

1372 // Helper: Growable text buffer for logging/accumulating text
1373 // (this could be called 'ImGuiTextBuilder' / 'ImGuiStringBuilder')
1374 struct ImGuiTextBuffer
1375 {
1376  ImVector<char> Buf;
1377  static char EmptyString[1];
1378 
1379  ImGuiTextBuffer() { }
1380  inline char operator[](int i) { IM_ASSERT(Buf.Data != NULL); return Buf.Data[i]; }
1381  const char* begin() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.front() : EmptyString; }
1382  const char* end() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.back() : EmptyString; } // Buf is zero-terminated, so end() will point on the zero-terminator
1383  int size() const { return Buf.Data ? Buf.Size - 1 : 0; }
1384  bool empty() { return Buf.Size <= 1; }
1385  void clear() { Buf.clear(); }
1386  void reserve(int capacity) { Buf.reserve(capacity); }
1387  const char* c_str() const { return Buf.Data ? Buf.Data : EmptyString; }
1388  IMGUI_API void appendf(const char* fmt, ...) IM_FMTARGS(2);
1389  IMGUI_API void appendfv(const char* fmt, va_list args) IM_FMTLIST(2);
1390 };

1392 // Helper: Key->Value storage
1393 // Typically you don't have to worry about this since a storage is held within each Window.
1394 // We use it to e.g. store collapse state for a tree (Int 0/1)
1395 // This is optimized for efficient lookup (dichotomy into a contiguous buffer) and rare insertion (typically tied to user interactions aka max once a frame)
1396 // You can use it as custom user storage for temporary values. Declare your own storage if, for example:
1397 // - You want to manipulate the open/close state of a particular sub-tree in your interface (tree node uses Int 0/1 to store their state).
1398 // - You want to store custom debug data easily without adding or editing structures in your code (probably not efficient, but convenient)
1399 // Types are NOT stored, so it is up to you to make sure your Key don't collide with different types.
1400 struct ImGuiStorage
1401 {
1402  struct Pair
1403  {
1404  ImGuiID key;
1405  union { int val_i; float val_f; void* val_p; };
1406  Pair(ImGuiID _key, int _val_i) { key = _key; val_i = _val_i; }
1407  Pair(ImGuiID _key, float _val_f) { key = _key; val_f = _val_f; }
1408  Pair(ImGuiID _key, void* _val_p) { key = _key; val_p = _val_p; }
1409  };
1410  ImVector<Pair> Data;
1411 
1412  // - Get***() functions find pair, never add/allocate. Pairs are sorted so a query is O(log N)
1413  // - Set***() functions find pair, insertion on demand if missing.
1414  // - Sorted insertion is costly, paid once. A typical frame shouldn't need to insert any new pair.
1415  void Clear() { Data.clear(); }
1416  IMGUI_API int GetInt(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0) const;
1417  IMGUI_API void SetInt(ImGuiID key, int val);
1418  IMGUI_API bool GetBool(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false) const;
1419  IMGUI_API void SetBool(ImGuiID key, bool val);
1420  IMGUI_API float GetFloat(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f) const;
1421  IMGUI_API void SetFloat(ImGuiID key, float val);
1422  IMGUI_API void* GetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key) const; // default_val is NULL
1423  IMGUI_API void SetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key, void* val);
1424 
1425  // - Get***Ref() functions finds pair, insert on demand if missing, return pointer. Useful if you intend to do Get+Set.
1426  // - References are only valid until a new value is added to the storage. Calling a Set***() function or a Get***Ref() function invalidates the pointer.
1427  // - A typical use case where this is convenient for quick hacking (e.g. add storage during a live Edit&Continue session if you can't modify existing struct)
1428  // float* pvar = ImGui::GetFloatRef(key); ImGui::SliderFloat("var", pvar, 0, 100.0f); some_var += *pvar;
1429  IMGUI_API int* GetIntRef(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0);
1430  IMGUI_API bool* GetBoolRef(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false);
1431  IMGUI_API float* GetFloatRef(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f);
1432  IMGUI_API void** GetVoidPtrRef(ImGuiID key, void* default_val = NULL);
1433 
1434  // Use on your own storage if you know only integer are being stored (open/close all tree nodes)
1435  IMGUI_API void SetAllInt(int val);
1436 
1437  // For quicker full rebuild of a storage (instead of an incremental one), you may add all your contents and then sort once.
1438  IMGUI_API void BuildSortByKey();
1439 };

1441 // Shared state of InputText(), passed as an argument to your callback when a ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback* flag is used.
1442 // The callback function should return 0 by default.
1443 // Callbacks (follow a flag name and see comments in ImGuiInputTextFlags_ declarations for more details)
1444 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCompletion: Callback on pressing TAB
1445 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackHistory: Callback on pressing Up/Down arrows
1446 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackAlways: Callback on each iteration
1447 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackCharFilter: Callback on character inputs to replace or discard them. Modify 'EventChar' to replace or discard, or return 1 in callback to discard.
1448 // - ImGuiInputTextFlags_CallbackResize: Callback on buffer capacity changes request (beyond 'buf_size' parameter value), allowing the string to grow.
1449 struct ImGuiInputTextCallbackData
1450 {
1451  ImGuiInputTextFlags EventFlag; // One ImGuiInputTextFlags_Callback* // Read-only
1452  ImGuiInputTextFlags Flags; // What user passed to InputText() // Read-only
1453  void* UserData; // What user passed to InputText() // Read-only
1454 
1455  // Arguments for the different callback events
1456  // - To modify the text buffer in a callback, prefer using the InsertChars() / DeleteChars() function. InsertChars() will take care of calling the resize callback if necessary.
1457  // - If you know your edits are not going to resize the underlying buffer allocation, you may modify the contents of 'Buf[]' directly. You need to update 'BufTextLen' accordingly (0 <= BufTextLen < BufSize) and set 'BufDirty'' to true so InputText can update its internal state.
1458  ImWchar EventChar; // Character input // Read-write // [CharFilter] Replace character with another one, or set to zero to drop. return 1 is equivalent to setting EventChar=0;
1459  ImGuiKey EventKey; // Key pressed (Up/Down/TAB) // Read-only // [Completion,History]
1460  char* Buf; // Text buffer // Read-write // [Resize] Can replace pointer / [Completion,History,Always] Only write to pointed data, don't replace the actual pointer!
1461  int BufTextLen; // Text length (in bytes) // Read-write // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Exclude zero-terminator storage. In C land: == strlen(some_text), in C++ land: string.length()
1462  int BufSize; // Buffer size (in bytes) = capacity+1 // Read-only // [Resize,Completion,History,Always] Include zero-terminator storage. In C land == ARRAYSIZE(my_char_array), in C++ land: string.capacity()+1
1463  bool BufDirty; // Set if you modify Buf/BufTextLen! // Write // [Completion,History,Always]
1464  int CursorPos; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always]
1465  int SelectionStart; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always] == to SelectionEnd when no selection)
1466  int SelectionEnd; // // Read-write // [Completion,History,Always]
1467 
1468  // Helper functions for text manipulation.
1469  // Use those function to benefit from the CallbackResize behaviors. Calling those function reset the selection.
1470  IMGUI_API ImGuiInputTextCallbackData();
1471  IMGUI_API void DeleteChars(int pos, int bytes_count);
1472  IMGUI_API void InsertChars(int pos, const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL);
1473  bool HasSelection() const { return SelectionStart != SelectionEnd; }

1513 // Helpers macros to generate 32-bits encoded colors
1514 #ifdef IMGUI_USE_BGRA_PACKED_COLOR
1515 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 16
1516 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
1517 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 0
1518 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
1519 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
1520 #else
1521 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 0
1522 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
1523 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 16
1524 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
1525 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
1526 #endif
1527 #define IM_COL32(R,G,B,A) (((ImU32)(A)<<IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(B)<<IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(G)<<IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(R)<<IM_COL32_R_SHIFT))
1528 #define IM_COL32_WHITE IM_COL32(255,255,255,255) // Opaque white = 0xFFFFFFFF
1529 #define IM_COL32_BLACK IM_COL32(0,0,0,255) // Opaque black
1530 #define IM_COL32_BLACK_TRANS IM_COL32(0,0,0,0) // Transparent black = 0x00000000
1531 
1532 // Helper: ImColor() implicity converts colors to either ImU32 (packed 4x1 byte) or ImVec4 (4x1 float)
1533 // Prefer using IM_COL32() macros if you want a guaranteed compile-time ImU32 for usage with ImDrawList API.
1534 // **Avoid storing ImColor! Store either u32 of ImVec4. This is not a full-featured color class. MAY OBSOLETE.
1535 // **None of the ImGui API are using ImColor directly but you can use it as a convenience to pass colors in either ImU32 or ImVec4 formats. Explicitly cast to ImU32 or ImVec4 if needed.
1536 struct ImColor
1537 {
1538  ImVec4 Value;
1539 
1540  ImColor() { Value.x = Value.y = Value.z = Value.w = 0.0f; }
1541  ImColor(int r, int g, int b, int a = 255) { float sc = 1.0f/255.0f; Value.x = (float)r * sc; Value.y = (float)g * sc; Value.z = (float)b * sc; Value.w = (float)a * sc; }
1542  ImColor(ImU32 rgba) { float sc = 1.0f/255.0f; Value.x = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_R_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.y = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_G_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.z = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_B_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.w = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_A_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; }
1543  ImColor(float r, float g, float b, float a = 1.0f) { Value.x = r; Value.y = g; Value.z = b; Value.w = a; }
1544  ImColor(const ImVec4& col) { Value = col; }
1545  inline operator ImU32() const { return ImGui::ColorConvertFloat4ToU32(Value); }
1546  inline operator ImVec4() const { return Value; }
1547 
1548  // FIXME-OBSOLETE: May need to obsolete/cleanup those helpers.
1549  inline void SetHSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f){ ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, Value.x, Value.y, Value.z); Value.w = a; }
1550  static ImColor HSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f) { float r,g,b; ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, r, g, b); return ImColor(r,g,b,a); }
1551 };

1553 // Helper: Manually clip large list of items.
1554 // If you are submitting lots of evenly spaced items and you have a random access to the list, you can perform coarse clipping based on visibility to save yourself from processing those items at all.
1555 // The clipper calculates the range of visible items and advance the cursor to compensate for the non-visible items we have skipped.
1556 // ImGui already clip items based on their bounds but it needs to measure text size to do so. Coarse clipping before submission makes this cost and your own data fetching/submission cost null.
1557 // Usage:
1558 // ImGuiListClipper clipper(1000); // we have 1000 elements, evenly spaced.
1559 // while (clipper.Step())
1560 // for (int i = clipper.DisplayStart; i < clipper.DisplayEnd; i++)
1561 // ImGui::Text("line number %d", i);
1562 // - Step 0: the clipper let you process the first element, regardless of it being visible or not, so we can measure the element height (step skipped if we passed a known height as second arg to constructor).
1563 // - Step 1: the clipper infer height from first element, calculate the actual range of elements to display, and position the cursor before the first element.
1564 // - (Step 2: dummy step only required if an explicit items_height was passed to constructor or Begin() and user call Step(). Does nothing and switch to Step 3.)
1565 // - Step 3: the clipper validate that we have reached the expected Y position (corresponding to element DisplayEnd), advance the cursor to the end of the list and then returns 'false' to end the loop.
1566 struct ImGuiListClipper
1567 {
1568  float StartPosY;
1569  float ItemsHeight;
1570  int ItemsCount, StepNo, DisplayStart, DisplayEnd;
1571 
1572  // items_count: Use -1 to ignore (you can call Begin later). Use INT_MAX if you don't know how many items you have (in which case the cursor won't be advanced in the final step).
1573  // items_height: Use -1.0f to be calculated automatically on first step. Otherwise pass in the distance between your items, typically GetTextLineHeightWithSpacing() or GetFrameHeightWithSpacing().
1574  // If you don't specify an items_height, you NEED to call Step(). If you specify items_height you may call the old Begin()/End() api directly, but prefer calling Step().
1575  ImGuiListClipper(int items_count = -1, float items_height = -1.0f) { Begin(items_count, items_height); } // NB: Begin() initialize every fields (as we allow user to call Begin/End multiple times on a same instance if they want).
1576  ~ImGuiListClipper() { IM_ASSERT(ItemsCount == -1); } // Assert if user forgot to call End() or Step() until false.
1577 
1578  IMGUI_API bool Step(); // Call until it returns false. The DisplayStart/DisplayEnd fields will be set and you can process/draw those items.
1579  IMGUI_API void Begin(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f); // Automatically called by constructor if you passed 'items_count' or by Step() in Step 1.
1580  IMGUI_API void End(); // Automatically called on the last call of Step() that returns false.
1581 };
1582 
1583 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1584 // Draw List
1585 // Hold a series of drawing commands. The user provides a renderer for ImDrawData which essentially contains an array of ImDrawList.
1586 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1587 
1588 // Draw callbacks for advanced uses.
1589 // NB- You most likely do NOT need to use draw callbacks just to create your own widget or customized UI rendering (you can poke into the draw list for that)
1590 // Draw callback may be useful for example, A) Change your GPU render state, B) render a complex 3D scene inside a UI element (without an intermediate texture/render target), etc.
1591 // The expected behavior from your rendering function is 'if (cmd.UserCallback != NULL) cmd.UserCallback(parent_list, cmd); else RenderTriangles()'
1592 typedef void (*ImDrawCallback)(const ImDrawList* parent_list, const ImDrawCmd* cmd);
1593 
1594 // Typically, 1 command = 1 GPU draw call (unless command is a callback)
1595 struct ImDrawCmd
1596 {
1597  unsigned int ElemCount; // Number of indices (multiple of 3) to be rendered as triangles. Vertices are stored in the callee ImDrawList's vtx_buffer[] array, indices in idx_buffer[].
1598  ImVec4 ClipRect; // Clipping rectangle (x1, y1, x2, y2). Subtract ImDrawData->DisplayPos to get clipping rectangle in "viewport" coordinates
1599  ImTextureID TextureId; // User-provided texture ID. Set by user in ImfontAtlas::SetTexID() for fonts or passed to Image*() functions. Ignore if never using images or multiple fonts atlas.
1600  ImDrawCallback UserCallback; // If != NULL, call the function instead of rendering the vertices. clip_rect and texture_id will be set normally.
1601  void* UserCallbackData; // The draw callback code can access this.
1602 
1603  ImDrawCmd() { ElemCount = 0; ClipRect.x = ClipRect.y = ClipRect.z = ClipRect.w = 0.0f; TextureId = (ImTextureID)NULL; UserCallback = NULL; UserCallbackData = NULL; }
1604 };

1606 // Vertex index (override with '#define ImDrawIdx unsigned int' inside in imconfig.h)
1607 #ifndef ImDrawIdx
1608 typedef unsigned short ImDrawIdx;
1609 #endif

1611 // Vertex layout
1612 #ifndef IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT
1613 struct ImDrawVert
1614 {
1615  ImVec2 pos;
1616  ImVec2 uv;
1617  ImU32 col;
1618 };
1619 #else
1620 // You can override the vertex format layout by defining IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT in imconfig.h
1621 // The code expect ImVec2 pos (8 bytes), ImVec2 uv (8 bytes), ImU32 col (4 bytes), but you can re-order them or add other fields as needed to simplify integration in your engine.
1622 // The type has to be described within the macro (you can either declare the struct or use a typedef)
1623 // NOTE: IMGUI DOESN'T CLEAR THE STRUCTURE AND DOESN'T CALL A CONSTRUCTOR SO ANY CUSTOM FIELD WILL BE UNINITIALIZED. IF YOU ADD EXTRA FIELDS (SUCH AS A 'Z' COORDINATES) YOU WILL NEED TO CLEAR THEM DURING RENDER OR TO IGNORE THEM.
1624 IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT;
1625 #endif

1627 // Draw channels are used by the Columns API to "split" the render list into different channels while building, so items of each column can be batched together.
1628 // You can also use them to simulate drawing layers and submit primitives in a different order than how they will be rendered.
1629 struct ImDrawChannel
1630 {
1631  ImVector<ImDrawCmd> CmdBuffer;
1632  ImVector<ImDrawIdx> IdxBuffer;
1633 };

1635 enum ImDrawCornerFlags_
1636 {
1637  ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft = 1 << 0, // 0x1
1638  ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight = 1 << 1, // 0x2
1639  ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft = 1 << 2, // 0x4
1640  ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight = 1 << 3, // 0x8
1641  ImDrawCornerFlags_Top = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight, // 0x3
1642  ImDrawCornerFlags_Bot = ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight, // 0xC
1643  ImDrawCornerFlags_Left = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft, // 0x5
1644  ImDrawCornerFlags_Right = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight, // 0xA
1645  ImDrawCornerFlags_All = 0xF // In your function calls you may use ~0 (= all bits sets) instead of ImDrawCornerFlags_All, as a convenience
1646 };
1647 
1648 enum ImDrawListFlags_
1649 {
1650  ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedLines = 1 << 0,
1651  ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedFill = 1 << 1
1652 };

1654 // Draw command list
1655 // This is the low-level list of polygons that ImGui functions are filling. At the end of the frame, all command lists are passed to your ImGuiIO::RenderDrawListFn function for rendering.
1656 // Each ImGui window contains its own ImDrawList. You can use ImGui::GetWindowDrawList() to access the current window draw list and draw custom primitives.
1657 // You can interleave normal ImGui:: calls and adding primitives to the current draw list.
1658 // All positions are generally in pixel coordinates (top-left at (0,0), bottom-right at io.DisplaySize), but you are totally free to apply whatever transformation matrix to want to the data (if you apply such transformation you'll want to apply it to ClipRect as well)
1659 // Important: Primitives are always added to the list and not culled (culling is done at higher-level by ImGui:: functions), if you use this API a lot consider coarse culling your drawn objects.
1660 struct ImDrawList
1661 {
1662  // This is what you have to render
1663  ImVector<ImDrawCmd> CmdBuffer; // Draw commands. Typically 1 command = 1 GPU draw call, unless the command is a callback.
1664  ImVector<ImDrawIdx> IdxBuffer; // Index buffer. Each command consume ImDrawCmd::ElemCount of those
1665  ImVector<ImDrawVert> VtxBuffer; // Vertex buffer.
1666  ImDrawListFlags Flags; // Flags, you may poke into these to adjust anti-aliasing settings per-primitive.
1667 
1668  // [Internal, used while building lists]
1669  const ImDrawListSharedData* _Data; // Pointer to shared draw data (you can use ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() to get the one from current ImGui context)
1670  const char* _OwnerName; // Pointer to owner window's name for debugging
1671  unsigned int _VtxCurrentIdx; // [Internal] == VtxBuffer.Size
1672  ImDrawVert* _VtxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within VtxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
1673  ImDrawIdx* _IdxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within IdxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
1674  ImVector<ImVec4> _ClipRectStack; // [Internal]
1675  ImVector<ImTextureID> _TextureIdStack; // [Internal]
1676  ImVector<ImVec2> _Path; // [Internal] current path building
1677  int _ChannelsCurrent; // [Internal] current channel number (0)
1678  int _ChannelsCount; // [Internal] number of active channels (1+)
1679  ImVector<ImDrawChannel> _Channels; // [Internal] draw channels for columns API (not resized down so _ChannelsCount may be smaller than _Channels.Size)
1680 
1681  // If you want to create ImDrawList instances, pass them ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() or create and use your own ImDrawListSharedData (so you can use ImDrawList without ImGui)
1682  ImDrawList(const ImDrawListSharedData* shared_data) { _Data = shared_data; _OwnerName = NULL; Clear(); }
1683  ~ImDrawList() { ClearFreeMemory(); }
1684  IMGUI_API void PushClipRect(ImVec2 clip_rect_min, ImVec2 clip_rect_max, bool intersect_with_current_clip_rect = false); // Render-level scissoring. This is passed down to your render function but not used for CPU-side coarse clipping. Prefer using higher-level ImGui::PushClipRect() to affect logic (hit-testing and widget culling)
1685  IMGUI_API void PushClipRectFullScreen();
1686  IMGUI_API void PopClipRect();
1687  IMGUI_API void PushTextureID(ImTextureID texture_id);
1688  IMGUI_API void PopTextureID();
1689  inline ImVec2 GetClipRectMin() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.x, cr.y); }
1690  inline ImVec2 GetClipRectMax() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.z, cr.w); }
1691

1743  inline void PrimWriteVtx(const ImVec2& pos, const ImVec2& uv, ImU32 col){ _VtxWritePtr->pos = pos; _VtxWritePtr->uv = uv; _VtxWritePtr->col = col; _VtxWritePtr++; _VtxCurrentIdx++; }

1750 // All draw data to render an ImGui frame
1751 // (NB: the style and the naming convention here is a little inconsistent but we preserve them for backward compatibility purpose)
1752 struct ImDrawData
1753 {
1754  bool Valid; // Only valid after Render() is called and before the next NewFrame() is called.
1755  ImDrawList** CmdLists; // Array of ImDrawList* to render. The ImDrawList are owned by ImGuiContext and only pointed to from here.
1756  int CmdListsCount; // Number of ImDrawList* to render
1757  int TotalIdxCount; // For convenience, sum of all ImDrawList's IdxBuffer.Size
1758  int TotalVtxCount; // For convenience, sum of all ImDrawList's VtxBuffer.Size
1759  ImVec2 DisplayPos; // Upper-left position of the viewport to render (== upper-left of the orthogonal projection matrix to use)
1760  ImVec2 DisplaySize; // Size of the viewport to render (== io.DisplaySize for the main viewport) (DisplayPos + DisplaySize == lower-right of the orthogonal projection matrix to use)
1761 
1762  // Functions
1763  ImDrawData() { Valid = false; Clear(); }
1764  ~ImDrawData() { Clear(); }
1765  void Clear() { Valid = false; CmdLists = NULL; CmdListsCount = TotalVtxCount = TotalIdxCount = 0; DisplayPos = DisplaySize = ImVec2(0.f, 0.f); } // The ImDrawList are owned by ImGuiContext!
1766  IMGUI_API void DeIndexAllBuffers(); // Helper to convert all buffers from indexed to non-indexed, in case you cannot render indexed. Note: this is slow and most likely a waste of resources. Always prefer indexed rendering!
1767  IMGUI_API void ScaleClipRects(const ImVec2& sc); // Helper to scale the ClipRect field of each ImDrawCmd. Use if your final output buffer is at a different scale than ImGui expects, or if there is a difference between your window resolution and framebuffer resolution.
1768 };

1770 struct ImFontConfig
1771 {
1772  void* FontData; // // TTF/OTF data
1773  int FontDataSize; // // TTF/OTF data size
1774  bool FontDataOwnedByAtlas; // true // TTF/OTF data ownership taken by the container ImFontAtlas (will delete memory itself).
1775  int FontNo; // 0 // Index of font within TTF/OTF file
1776  float SizePixels; // // Size in pixels for rasterizer (more or less maps to the resulting font height).
1777  int OversampleH; // 3 // Rasterize at higher quality for sub-pixel positioning. We don't use sub-pixel positions on the Y axis.
1778  int OversampleV; // 1 // Rasterize at higher quality for sub-pixel positioning. We don't use sub-pixel positions on the Y axis.
1779  bool PixelSnapH; // false // Align every glyph to pixel boundary. Useful e.g. if you are merging a non-pixel aligned font with the default font. If enabled, you can set OversampleH/V to 1.
1780  ImVec2 GlyphExtraSpacing; // 0, 0 // Extra spacing (in pixels) between glyphs. Only X axis is supported for now.
1781  ImVec2 GlyphOffset; // 0, 0 // Offset all glyphs from this font input.
1782  const ImWchar* GlyphRanges; // NULL // Pointer to a user-provided list of Unicode range (2 value per range, values are inclusive, zero-terminated list). THE ARRAY DATA NEEDS TO PERSIST AS LONG AS THE FONT IS ALIVE.
1783  float GlyphMinAdvanceX; // 0 // Minimum AdvanceX for glyphs, set Min to align font icons, set both Min/Max to enforce mono-space font
1784  float GlyphMaxAdvanceX; // FLT_MAX // Maximum AdvanceX for glyphs
1785  bool MergeMode; // false // Merge into previous ImFont, so you can combine multiple inputs font into one ImFont (e.g. ASCII font + icons + Japanese glyphs). You may want to use GlyphOffset.y when merge font of different heights.
1786  unsigned int RasterizerFlags; // 0x00 // Settings for custom font rasterizer (e.g. ImGuiFreeType). Leave as zero if you aren't using one.
1787  float RasterizerMultiply; // 1.0f // Brighten (>1.0f) or darken (<1.0f) font output. Brightening small fonts may be a good workaround to make them more readable.
1788 
1789  // [Internal]
1790  char Name[40]; // Name (strictly to ease debugging)
1791  ImFont* DstFont;
1792 
1793  IMGUI_API ImFontConfig();
1794 };

1796 struct ImFontGlyph
1797 {
1798  ImWchar Codepoint; // 0x0000..0xFFFF
1799  float AdvanceX; // Distance to next character (= data from font + ImFontConfig::GlyphExtraSpacing.x baked in)
1800  float X0, Y0, X1, Y1; // Glyph corners
1801  float U0, V0, U1, V1; // Texture coordinates
1802 };

1804 enum ImFontAtlasFlags_
1805 {
1806  ImFontAtlasFlags_None = 0,
1807  ImFontAtlasFlags_NoPowerOfTwoHeight = 1 << 0, // Don't round the height to next power of two
1808  ImFontAtlasFlags_NoMouseCursors = 1 << 1 // Don't build software mouse cursors into the atlas

1810 
1811 // Load and rasterize multiple TTF/OTF fonts into a same texture. The font atlas will build a single texture holding:
1812 // - One or more fonts.
1813 // - Custom graphics data needed to render the shapes needed by Dear ImGui.
1814 // - Mouse cursor shapes for software cursor rendering (unless setting 'Flags |= ImFontAtlasFlags_NoMouseCursors' in the font atlas).
1815 // It is the user-code responsibility to setup/build the atlas, then upload the pixel data into a texture accessible by your graphics api.
1816 // - Optionally, call any of the AddFont*** functions. If you don't call any, the default font embedded in the code will be loaded for you.
1817 // - Call GetTexDataAsAlpha8() or GetTexDataAsRGBA32() to build and retrieve pixels data.
1818 // - Upload the pixels data into a texture within your graphics system (see imgui_impl_xxxx.cpp examples)
1819 // - Call SetTexID(my_tex_id); and pass the pointer/identifier to your texture in a format natural to your graphics API.
1820 // This value will be passed back to you during rendering to identify the texture. Read FAQ entry about ImTextureID for more details.
1821 // Common pitfalls:
1822 // - If you pass a 'glyph_ranges' array to AddFont*** functions, you need to make sure that your array persist up until the
1823 // atlas is build (when calling GetTexData*** or Build()). We only copy the pointer, not the data.
1824 // - Important: By default, AddFontFromMemoryTTF() takes ownership of the data. Even though we are not writing to it, we will free the pointer on destruction.
1825 // You can set font_cfg->FontDataOwnedByAtlas=false to keep ownership of your data and it won't be freed,
1826 // - Even though many functions are suffixed with "TTF", OTF data is supported just as well.
1827 // - This is an old API and it is currently awkward for those and and various other reasons! We will address them in the future!
1828 struct ImFontAtlas
1829 {
1830  IMGUI_API ImFontAtlas();
1831  IMGUI_API ~ImFontAtlas();
1832  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFont(const ImFontConfig* font_cfg);
1833  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontDefault(const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL);
1834  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromFileTTF(const char* filename, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL);
1835  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryTTF(void* font_data, int font_size, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // Note: Transfer ownership of 'ttf_data' to ImFontAtlas! Will be deleted after destruction of the atlas. Set font_cfg->FontDataOwnedByAtlas=false to keep ownership of your data and it won't be freed.
1836  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryCompressedTTF(const void* compressed_font_data, int compressed_font_size, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // 'compressed_font_data' still owned by caller. Compress with binary_to_compressed_c.cpp.
1837  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryCompressedBase85TTF(const char* compressed_font_data_base85, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // 'compressed_font_data_base85' still owned by caller. Compress with binary_to_compressed_c.cpp with -base85 parameter.
1838  IMGUI_API void ClearInputData(); // Clear input data (all ImFontConfig structures including sizes, TTF data, glyph ranges, etc.) = all the data used to build the texture and fonts.
1839  IMGUI_API void ClearTexData(); // Clear output texture data (CPU side). Saves RAM once the texture has been copied to graphics memory.
1840  IMGUI_API void ClearFonts(); // Clear output font data (glyphs storage, UV coordinates).
1841  IMGUI_API void Clear(); // Clear all input and output.
1842 
1843  // Build atlas, retrieve pixel data.
1844  // User is in charge of copying the pixels into graphics memory (e.g. create a texture with your engine). Then store your texture handle with SetTexID().
1845  // The pitch is always = Width * BytesPerPixels (1 or 4)
1846  // Building in RGBA32 format is provided for convenience and compatibility, but note that unless you manually manipulate or copy color data into
1847  // the texture (e.g. when using the AddCustomRect*** api), then the RGB pixels emitted will always be white (~75% of memory/bandwidth waste.
1848  IMGUI_API bool Build(); // Build pixels data. This is called automatically for you by the GetTexData*** functions.
1849  IMGUI_API bool IsBuilt() { return Fonts.Size > 0 && (TexPixelsAlpha8 != NULL || TexPixelsRGBA32 != NULL); }
1850  IMGUI_API void GetTexDataAsAlpha8(unsigned char** out_pixels, int* out_width, int* out_height, int* out_bytes_per_pixel = NULL); // 1 byte per-pixel
1851  IMGUI_API void GetTexDataAsRGBA32(unsigned char** out_pixels, int* out_width, int* out_height, int* out_bytes_per_pixel = NULL); // 4 bytes-per-pixel
1852  void SetTexID(ImTextureID id) { TexID = id; }
1853 
1854  //-------------------------------------------
1855  // Glyph Ranges
1856  //-------------------------------------------
1857 
1858  // Helpers to retrieve list of common Unicode ranges (2 value per range, values are inclusive, zero-terminated list)
1859  // NB: Make sure that your string are UTF-8 and NOT in your local code page. In C++11, you can create UTF-8 string literal using the u8"Hello world" syntax. See FAQ for details.
1860  // NB: Consider using GlyphRangesBuilder to build glyph ranges from textual data.
1861  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesDefault(); // Basic Latin, Extended Latin
1862  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesKorean(); // Default + Korean characters
1863  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesJapanese(); // Default + Hiragana, Katakana, Half-Width, Selection of 1946 Ideographs
1864  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesChineseFull(); // Default + Half-Width + Japanese Hiragana/Katakana + full set of about 21000 CJK Unified Ideographs
1865  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesChineseSimplifiedCommon();// Default + Half-Width + Japanese Hiragana/Katakana + set of 2500 CJK Unified Ideographs for common simplified Chinese
1866  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesCyrillic(); // Default + about 400 Cyrillic characters
1867  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesThai(); // Default + Thai characters
1868 
1869  // Helpers to build glyph ranges from text data. Feed your application strings/characters to it then call BuildRanges().
1870  struct GlyphRangesBuilder
1871  {
1872  ImVector<unsigned char> UsedChars; // Store 1-bit per Unicode code point (0=unused, 1=used)
1873  GlyphRangesBuilder() { UsedChars.resize(0x10000 / 8); memset(UsedChars.Data, 0, 0x10000 / 8); }
1874  bool GetBit(int n) const { return (UsedChars[n >> 3] & (1 << (n & 7))) != 0; }
1875  void SetBit(int n) { UsedChars[n >> 3] |= 1 << (n & 7); } // Set bit 'c' in the array
1876  void AddChar(ImWchar c) { SetBit(c); } // Add character
1877  IMGUI_API void AddText(const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL); // Add string (each character of the UTF-8 string are added)
1878  IMGUI_API void AddRanges(const ImWchar* ranges); // Add ranges, e.g. builder.AddRanges(ImFontAtlas::GetGlyphRangesDefault()) to force add all of ASCII/Latin+Ext
1879  IMGUI_API void BuildRanges(ImVector<ImWchar>* out_ranges); // Output new ranges
1880  };
1881 
1882  //-------------------------------------------
1883  // Custom Rectangles/Glyphs API
1884  //-------------------------------------------
1885 
1886  // You can request arbitrary rectangles to be packed into the atlas, for your own purposes. After calling Build(), you can query the rectangle position and render your pixels.
1887  // You can also request your rectangles to be mapped as font glyph (given a font + Unicode point), so you can render e.g. custom colorful icons and use them as regular glyphs.
1888  struct CustomRect
1889  {
1890  unsigned int ID; // Input // User ID. Use <0x10000 to map into a font glyph, >=0x10000 for other/internal/custom texture data.
1891  unsigned short Width, Height; // Input // Desired rectangle dimension
1892  unsigned short X, Y; // Output // Packed position in Atlas
1893  float GlyphAdvanceX; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID<0x10000): glyph xadvance
1894  ImVec2 GlyphOffset; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID<0x10000): glyph display offset
1895  ImFont* Font; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID<0x10000): target font
1896  CustomRect() { ID = 0xFFFFFFFF; Width = Height = 0; X = Y = 0xFFFF; GlyphAdvanceX = 0.0f; GlyphOffset = ImVec2(0,0); Font = NULL; }
1897  bool IsPacked() const { return X != 0xFFFF; }
1898  };
1899 
1900  IMGUI_API int AddCustomRectRegular(unsigned int id, int width, int height); // Id needs to be >= 0x10000. Id >= 0x80000000 are reserved for ImGui and ImDrawList
1901  IMGUI_API int AddCustomRectFontGlyph(ImFont* font, ImWchar id, int width, int height, float advance_x, const ImVec2& offset = ImVec2(0,0)); // Id needs to be < 0x10000 to register a rectangle to map into a specific font.
1902  const CustomRect* GetCustomRectByIndex(int index) const { if (index < 0) return NULL; return &CustomRects[index]; }
1903 
1904  // [Internal]
1905  IMGUI_API void CalcCustomRectUV(const CustomRect* rect, ImVec2* out_uv_min, ImVec2* out_uv_max);
1906  IMGUI_API bool GetMouseCursorTexData(ImGuiMouseCursor cursor, ImVec2* out_offset, ImVec2* out_size, ImVec2 out_uv_border[2], ImVec2 out_uv_fill[2]);
1907

1911 
1912  bool Locked; // Marked as Locked by ImGui::NewFrame() so attempt to modify the atlas will assert.
1913  ImFontAtlasFlags Flags; // Build flags (see ImFontAtlasFlags_)
1914  ImTextureID TexID; // User data to refer to the texture once it has been uploaded to user's graphic systems. It is passed back to you during rendering via the ImDrawCmd structure.
1915  int TexDesiredWidth; // Texture width desired by user before Build(). Must be a power-of-two. If have many glyphs your graphics API have texture size restrictions you may want to increase texture width to decrease height.
1916  int TexGlyphPadding; // Padding between glyphs within texture in pixels. Defaults to 1.
1917 
1918  // [Internal]
1919  // NB: Access texture data via GetTexData*() calls! Which will setup a default font for you.
1920  unsigned char* TexPixelsAlpha8; // 1 component per pixel, each component is unsigned 8-bit. Total size = TexWidth * TexHeight
1921  unsigned int* TexPixelsRGBA32; // 4 component per pixel, each component is unsigned 8-bit. Total size = TexWidth * TexHeight * 4
1922  int TexWidth; // Texture width calculated during Build().
1923  int TexHeight; // Texture height calculated during Build().
1924  ImVec2 TexUvScale; // = (1.0f/TexWidth, 1.0f/TexHeight)
1925  ImVec2 TexUvWhitePixel; // Texture coordinates to a white pixel
1926  ImVector<ImFont*> Fonts; // Hold all the fonts returned by AddFont*. Fonts[0] is the default font upon calling ImGui::NewFrame(), use ImGui::PushFont()/PopFont() to change the current font.
1927  ImVector<CustomRect> CustomRects; // Rectangles for packing custom texture data into the atlas.
1928  ImVector<ImFontConfig> ConfigData; // Internal data
1929  int CustomRectIds[1]; // Identifiers of custom texture rectangle used by ImFontAtlas/ImDrawList
1930 };

1932 // Font runtime data and rendering
1933 // ImFontAtlas automatically loads a default embedded font for you when you call GetTexDataAsAlpha8() or GetTexDataAsRGBA32().
1934 struct ImFont
1935 {
1936  // Members: Hot ~62/78 bytes
1937  float FontSize; // <user set> // Height of characters, set during loading (don't change after loading)
1938  float Scale; // = 1.f // Base font scale, multiplied by the per-window font scale which you can adjust with SetFontScale()
1939  ImVec2 DisplayOffset; // = (0.f,0.f) // Offset font rendering by xx pixels
1940  ImVector<ImFontGlyph> Glyphs; // // All glyphs.
1941  ImVector<float> IndexAdvanceX; // // Sparse. Glyphs->AdvanceX in a directly indexable way (more cache-friendly, for CalcTextSize functions which are often bottleneck in large UI).
1942  ImVector<ImWchar> IndexLookup; // // Sparse. Index glyphs by Unicode code-point.
1943  const ImFontGlyph* FallbackGlyph; // == FindGlyph(FontFallbackChar)
1944  float FallbackAdvanceX; // == FallbackGlyph->AdvanceX
1945  ImWchar FallbackChar; // = '?' // Replacement glyph if one isn't found. Only set via SetFallbackChar()
1946 
1947  // Members: Cold ~18/26 bytes
1948  short ConfigDataCount; // ~ 1 // Number of ImFontConfig involved in creating this font. Bigger than 1 when merging multiple font sources into one ImFont.
1949  ImFontConfig* ConfigData; // // Pointer within ContainerAtlas->ConfigData
1950  ImFontAtlas* ContainerAtlas; // // What we has been loaded into
1951  float Ascent, Descent; // // Ascent: distance from top to bottom of e.g. 'A' [0..FontSize]
1952  bool DirtyLookupTables;
1953  int MetricsTotalSurface;// // Total surface in pixels to get an idea of the font rasterization/texture cost (not exact, we approximate the cost of padding between glyphs)
1954 
1955  // Methods
1956  IMGUI_API ImFont();
1957  IMGUI_API ~ImFont();
1958  IMGUI_API void ClearOutputData();
1959  IMGUI_API void BuildLookupTable();
1960  IMGUI_API const ImFontGlyph*FindGlyph(ImWchar c) const;
1961  IMGUI_API const ImFontGlyph*FindGlyphNoFallback(ImWchar c) const;
1962  IMGUI_API void SetFallbackChar(ImWchar c);
1963  float GetCharAdvance(ImWchar c) const { return ((int)c < IndexAdvanceX.Size) ? IndexAdvanceX[(int)c] : FallbackAdvanceX; }
1964  bool IsLoaded() const { return ContainerAtlas != NULL; }
1965  const char* GetDebugName() const { return ConfigData ? ConfigData->Name : "<unknown>"; }
1966 
1967  // 'max_width' stops rendering after a certain width (could be turned into a 2d size). FLT_MAX to disable.
1968  // 'wrap_width' enable automatic word-wrapping across multiple lines to fit into given width. 0.0f to disable.
1969  IMGUI_API ImVec2 CalcTextSizeA(float size, float max_width, float wrap_width, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL, const char** remaining = NULL) const; // utf8
1970  IMGUI_API const char* CalcWordWrapPositionA(float scale, const char* text, const char* text_end, float wrap_width) const;
1971  IMGUI_API void RenderChar(ImDrawList* draw_list, float size, ImVec2 pos, ImU32 col, ImWchar c) const;
1972  IMGUI_API void RenderText(ImDrawList* draw_list, float size, ImVec2 pos, ImU32 col, const ImVec4& clip_rect, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end, float wrap_width = 0.0f, bool cpu_fine_clip = false) const;
1973
